body.p: Your Petitioner Moses Mullins says that at the March Term 1861 of the Laurel Circuit court he was fined $15. for an alleged disturbance of Religious Worship. and afterwards upon petition he obtained a respite thereon, which expired on the day of 1863 -- He now repeats all the statements made in his original petition and says they are true, he did not intend to disturb the meeting and he was wholey unable to pay said fine, but replevied the same, and the sheriff is now endeavoring to coerce the same out of his surities -- and he is less able to pay now than he was at the time of the respite -- that the rebel army last fall under Kirby Smith took from him pretty much all he had which was but little, but that little greatly needed for the support of his family, and his neighbors found about the same way -- He says the fine cannot possibly be paid without serious oppression, altho' it is small -- he therefore prays your Excellency to remit it --
Sworn to before me by Moses Mullins this 9 day of March 1863.
We are neighbors of Moses Mullins, know his condition and do not hesitate to endorse the facts above stated as being true, and believe that the fine ought to be remitted

Wm T Young
H C Mason
Wm L. Burnett
Philip Swaner
Riley Wadkins
J Cothers
J F Blalek
S swaner
J jonson
B M Porter
C M Carter
L Jons
C Wadkins

Laurel Cir. Ct
Remitted except Five dollars & costs
J F Robinson
$15. } Mis.
M. Mullins
Issd Apr. 28. 1863 --
